item.title: Story of China
item.description:
Trade war, communist party, ‚ÄúXinjiang concentration‚Äù, Covid-19, Huaiwei-5G, Tiktok‚Ä¶, When was your last time hearing something positive of China? Have you heard about China alleviating hundreds of millions of people out of extreme poverty, showing its incredible resilience in overcoming the effects of economic crisis, decisive implementation of rural revitalization strategy, achieving carbon neutrality before 2060 (keep in mind that China is still a developing country)‚Ä¶? Sometimes thing is not as simple as we think‚Ä¶ People definitely need a more objective way, especially abandoning their ideology, to understand China, and the people living there. When we look at what is happening in the West, we know that their systems are facing unprecedented challenges. However, no offense, the West is still judging the rest of the world with its superiority and arrogance. Now, it is time to cooperate and embrace diversities of global governance in key issues such as climate change, green energy etc.

Here is a Youtube channel to recommend: National Committee on U.S.-China Relations

item.title: R packages and tips (keep updating)
item.description:
Tidyverse is a revolutionary package. I started from learning base R by taking some courses in Uni two years ago. However, the more I learned, the more I felt confused because there were always two solutions to one R question in stack overflow. Since then I realized the existence of tidyverse, especially from dplyr, and gradually switched to be a tidyverse person.

This is the tidyverse family:

Here is the tidyverse learning material from Dr.¬†Olivier Gimenez:

üçæü§™ Just updated my introduction to the #tidyverse to manipulate & visualise data in #rstat comments welcome ü§ó #datascience #davaviz
Slides: https://t.co/O1gKF6Eenh
Code: https://t.co/As9bkXY9GZ pic.twitter.com/Uo7Hk9jj7d

— Olivier Gimenez üññ (@oaggimenez) October 22, 2020


Here is the check and to-do list of my R (keep on updating):

  • tibble
  • readr
  • dplyr
  • tidyr
  • forcats
  • ggplot2

tip.1 use regular expression either on axis or legends if sub/superscript, Greek letters needed;

library(tidyverse)
library(scales)
ylab(expression(delta^{13}*"C"[CO2]))
scale_color_manual(name = "",
                   values = c("#ff6600", "#00b33c"),
                   labels = c(expression(with ^{13}*"C lipids"), expression(without ^{13}*"C lipids")))

  • stringr

  • purrr

  • readxl

  • lubricate

  • glue

Tidymodels is definitely my next package to learn after all the packages above are checked.

By the way, I create this website not only to show my information in academics, but also want to share some insights or knowledge I have acquired, for example, creating a website for free.

item.title: Creating a website (keep updating)
item.description:
This is my first time to create a website with the help of R package blogdown and Hugo. It was not as hard as I have imagined in the beginning, but as time going on, I found it necessary to know a little bit about all the underlying technologies like HTML, CSS, Hugo templating language, and JavaScript. I will keep updating if I am making a progress and keep in touch!

Usefull resources:

Alison‚Äôs website
